description: From Middle English inspiriten, equivalent to in- +‎ spirit.

verbs.description: inspirit (third-person singular simple present inspirits, present participle inspiriting, simple past and past participle inspirited)

entries.meaning: To strengthen or hearten; give impetus or vigour.
examples: Ah! must wee live, and see so sudden dead
The Life that late our lives inspirited?

entries.meaning: To fill or imbue with spirit.
examples: […]  the Assurance we have of the Existence of Beings above our Sense, and of Thee, (the great Exemplar of thy Works) comes from Thee, the All-True, and Perfect, who hast thus communicated thy-self more immediately to us, so as in some manner to inhabit within our Souls; Thou who art Original Soul, diffusive, vital in all, inspiriting the Whole.
